speaker: James
text: The article's title alone is enough to make you wince: '150 Years of Pain'. We're talking about the First Industrial Revolution, and the claim is that the coming AI revolution will be just as, if not more, brutal.

speaker: Elena
text: Oh, come on. 'Brutal'? That's a bit dramatic, isn't it? We're not talking about children up chimneys this time. We have education, social safety nets, a far more advanced society.

speaker: James
text: Are we? The article suggests that 'collective amnesia' about the original industrialisation means we're walking straight into the same trap. It wasn't a quick adjustment; it was generations of upheaval. From 1776 to the end of the Second World War.

speaker: Elena
text: But that's comparing apples and oranges. The Luddites, sure, they had a point, but eventually, new jobs emerged. Isn't the whole 'education is the solution' argument about preparing people for those new roles?

speaker: James
text: The article explicitly calls that view 'too simplistic and wrong'. It made millions 'suddenly become unemployed'. Moving from a farm to a factory, or worse, prostitution. That wasn't an 'adjustment', Elena. It was a catastrophic collapse of livelihoods for vast swathes of the population.

speaker: Elena
text: Catastrophic... I mean, I agree it was awful, but the long-term outcome was prosperity, wasn't it? For the nations that industrialised, anyway.

speaker: James
text: For the early entrants, yes. But that prosperity was built on an early entrant advantage, often at the expense of others. Remember what we covered in 'The Rise of the West Was Based on Luck'?

speaker: Elena
text: I do. The article mentions 'subjugation and colonisation'. That's a pretty dark undercurrent.

speaker: James
text: Dark, and accurate. Ricardo's 'comparative advantage' and Smith's 'free trade' crushed economies outside the West. China, India, reduced to captive markets. The Opium Wars? Pure economic coercion.

speaker: Elena
text: So, the 'revolution' wasn't benign. It was violent, globally speaking. Okay, I'll give you that. But what does that mean for us now?

speaker: James
text: It means if you believe education is the panacea, you're abandoning a large chunk of society. The article says, 'stupid or lazy people will always be less attractive to employers'. Harsh, but true.

speaker: Elena
text: No, that's completely wrong, and I'll tell you why. That's a convenient way to dismiss the need for social support. Not everyone can be a coding prodigy, but that doesn't make them 'lazy'.

speaker: James
text: It's not about being a prodigy. It's about global competition. If companies can hire 'smart and hardworking people from other countries', why would they pick anyone less from their own? We're all competing globally now.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a race to the bottom! Are you suggesting we just let people fall through the cracks because they can't compete with the entire planet?

speaker: James
text: The article asks: 'Just because you are stupid, or lazy, or both, should you be condemned to a life of misery and unemployment?' It doesn't offer a solution, only points out the brutal reality employers face.

speaker: Elena
text: And it makes the point that highly educated populations don't necessarily create *that many* jobs. Google, Apple, Microsoftâ€”

speaker: James
text: Hire relatively few people. Even with their ecosystems. Foxconn, with half a million employees, is automating thousands of jobs with robots.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, that's a problem. I thought the service sector would be the buffer, but AI is eating into that too.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. The 'renewable and battery revolution' article makes a similar point about disruption. Some win, many fail.

speaker: Elena
text: So, if education isn't the solution, what *is*? Stop free trade? De-industrialise? Become autarchic? Those sound like 1930s solutions.

speaker: James
text: King Canute. You can't turn back the tide of innovation. The article makes that clear.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a deeply pessimistic, almost fatalistic, view. We're not helpless. We can choose how we manage this transition.

speaker: James
text: The problem is, our problems may be 'even worse than in the first wave of industrialisation'.

speaker: Elena
text: Worse? How?

speaker: James
text: We have no 'population release valve'. No 'empty continent presided over by a government willing to welcome the huddled masses'. In the 19th century, millions fled Europe to America, Canada, Argentina.

speaker: Elena
text: Wait, really? That many went?

speaker: James
text: Millions. It was a pressure cooker, and emigration provided an escape. Where do people go now?

speaker: Elena
text: That's... actually devastating. I hadn't considered the lack of that kind of safety valve. There's no 'new world' to absorb the displaced.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. The West's rise, as we discussed in 'The Rise of the West Was Based on Luck', was partly due to this vast, open frontier. That luck has run out.

speaker: Elena
text: So, we're talking about a multi-generational, violent upheaval, with no escape route for the unemployed and a globalised workforce actively seeking the 'best' rather than the 'available' in their own country.

speaker: James
text: And the article's conclusion is blunt: 'First, Get Rid Of Expensive Westerners. Second, Get Rid Of People Entirely'. That's the automation trajectory.

speaker: Elena
text: Ha! Good luck with that. No, but seriously... if education isn't the solution, and there's no mass emigration, what *does* a government do?

speaker: James
text: The article doesn't offer easy answers. It's more about understanding the scale of the challenge based on historical precedent. The first 'revolution' wasn't a gentle evolution.

speaker: Elena
text: No, it clearly wasn't. Reading about the suffering, the literal bombing of Chinese cities to force trade... it paints a very different picture from the one taught in schools.

speaker: James
text: A picture we seem to have forgotten. And now we face something similar, perhaps even more acute, given the lack of options.

speaker: Elena
text: I don't want to agree with you on this, but the historical data, especially about the duration and the global impact, doesn't leave much room for the usual progressive optimism. It's a much bigger beast.

speaker: James
text: A brutal beast. And one that's already underway.

speaker: Elena
text: So, just... brace for impact?

speaker: James
text: Perhaps. Or, at least, understand the historical forces at play before proposing quick fixes.

speaker: Elena
text: Hmm. That's a chilling thought for a Friday evening.
